skill.name: qiskit
skill.description: IBM quantum computing framework. Use when targeting IBM Quantum hardware, working with Qiskit Runtime for production workloads, or needing IBM optimization tools. Best for IBM hardware execution, quantum error mitigation, and enterprise quantum computing. For Google hardware use cirq; for gradient-based quantum ML use pennylane; for open quantum system simulations use qutip.
skill.summary: Build, optimize, and run quantum circuits on IBM Quantum hardware and simulators
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: All 409 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The skill is pure markdown documentation containing Python code examples for IBM Qiskit quantum computing. The static analyzer incorrectly interprets markdown code block delimiters as command execution and flags legitimate quantum computing terminology as malware indicators.

static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Markdown code block delimiters (```python, ```bash) are documentation markers, not shell command execution. All occurrences are in .md documentation files containing legitimate quantum computing examples.

Quantum algorithms (VQE, QAOA, Shor's) are legitimate computational methods for chemistry, optimization, and factoring. These are not cryptographic vulnerabilities but standard quantum computing algorithms.
Quantum computing terms (execute, run, backend, connection) match C2 keywords superficially but represent legitimate quantum computing concepts, not command-and-control malware.
Documentation URLs (quantum.ibm.com, qiskit.org) are legitimate references to IBM Quantum and Qiskit official documentation, not external data exfiltration.
Examples of saving circuit diagrams (circuit.tex, circuit.png) are legitimate documentation for visualization features.
Checking backend status in quantum computing (least_busy, backend properties) is standard practice for selecting quantum hardware, not system reconnaissance.

content.value_statement: Quantum computing enables solving complex optimization, chemistry, and machine learning problems that are intractable for classical computers. Qiskit provides the tools to build quantum circuits, optimize them for IBM hardware, and execute on real quantum processors or simulators.
actual_capabilities: Create quantum circuits with gates (H, X, Y, Z, CNOT, rotations)
Execute circuits on local simulators or IBM Quantum hardware
Transpile and optimize circuits for specific quantum backends
Implement algorithms like VQE, QAOA, and Grover's search
Visualize circuits, results, and quantum states (Bloch sphere, histograms)
limitations: Requires IBM Quantum account for hardware access (free tier available)
Real quantum hardware has limited qubit counts and error rates
Not suitable for classical computing problems better solved by traditional methods

use_cases.title: Simulate molecular systems
use_cases.description: Use VQE algorithm to compute ground state energies of molecules for drug discovery and materials science research.

use_cases.title: Solve combinatorial problems
use_cases.description: Apply QAOA to solve MaxCut, portfolio optimization, and scheduling problems that benefit from quantum speedup.

use_cases.title: Build quantum classifiers
use_cases.description: Create quantum kernels and neural networks for machine learning tasks using Qiskit Machine Learning.

prompt_templates.title: Create basic circuit
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to create a Bell state entangled circuit with Qiskit that measures both qubits

prompt_templates.title: Run on hardware
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me transpile my circuit for ibm_brisbane backend and run it using the SamplerV2 primitive

prompt_templates.title: Implement VQE
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a complete VQE implementation using Qiskit Runtime Session to find the ground state energy of H2 molecule

prompt_templates.title: Optimize circuits
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to optimize a quantum circuit for hardware execution using optimization_level=3 and best practices

output_examples.input: Create a 3-qubit GHZ state circuit and run it on a simulator

best_practices: Start with local simulators (StatevectorSampler) to validate circuits before using expensive hardware time
Always transpile circuits before execution on hardware with optimization_level=3 for production workloads
Use Session mode for iterative algorithms (VQE, QAOA) and Batch mode for parallel independent jobs
anti_patterns: Running untranspiled circuits directly on hardware (causes high error rates and queue rejections)
Using Estimator for sampling tasks or Sampler for expectation values (mismatched primitives)
Skipping error mitigation on real hardware (resilience_level should match accuracy requirements)

faq.question: Do I need an IBM Quantum account?
faq.answer: No account needed for local simulators. Create free IBM Quantum account at quantum.ibm.com for hardware access.

faq.question: How many qubits are available?
faq.answer: IBM Quantum offers 100+ qubit systems. Free tier provides access to smaller devices for learning.

faq.question: What is the difference between Sampler and Estimator?
faq.answer: Sampler returns measurement outcomes (counts). Estimator returns expectation values of observables (energies).

faq.question: Can I run circuits without internet?
faq.answer: Yes, local simulators (StatevectorSampler, Aer) work offline. Cloud backends require internet connection.

faq.question: What is transpilation?
faq.answer: Transpilation converts circuits to the native gate set and topology of target quantum hardware for execution.

faq.question: How long do quantum jobs take?
faq.answer: Simulator jobs are instant. Hardware jobs queue based on system load, typically minutes to hours.
